title: Facial recognition laws go well beyond security
text:
As the further details emerged, leading cyber security expert Nigel Phair warned the planned redrafting should include limiting organisations who would have access to biometric data and protections against misuse.

Warning "mission creep" from the laws could prompt legitimate fears of saturation surveillance and even use similar to that of countries including China, Mr Phair said the Coalition should make the case for why the laws are necessary.

"We need to know which agencies get access to it and why," he said.

"Every agency thinks they're important and should get access to it. You could argue maybe they're right and they should, but I think most people on the street would argue they shouldn't.

"Essentially it should be limited to state and Commonwealth policing agencies, ICAC equivalents, and of course ASIO. That's about it."

Mr Phair, director of UNSW Canberra Cyber, said regular public reporting should include data on offences investigated and disclosure of where successful convictions were based solely on records held in a federal database.

He said mission creep could "quite easily" see facial recognition used in ways most Australians would object to.

Hong Kong authorities have access to artificial intelligence software that can match faces from protest footage, and experts say its use is ubiquitous in mainland China, used for law enforcement and "social credit" monitoring of the population.

Advertisement

"The City of Westminister [in England], which is only about a mile by a mile, has a 100 per cent saturation from CCTV cameras and obviously subsequent monitoring thereof," Mr Phair said.

Mr Dutton said the legislation was good and necessary.

'Diabolical' politics

"It just reflects the reality now of people having their digital identity stolen online as well. This is a big business for organised crime groups.''

One member of the respected parliamentary committee said the politics of facial recognition was "diabolical" and there had been no public argument from the government for more than a year about why the database was required.

Committee members were not opposed to the database per se, but rather wanted to see more privacy safeguards.

"Instead of writing 100 plus recommendations we decided to start over and consider those principles," the MP said.

Labor's shadow attorney-general, Mark Dreyfus, said the public needed assurances the scheme wouldn't be abused.

"We've got technology that is racing ahead, that is giving potentially undreamed-of power to our security agencies and our police forces. It has to be surrounded by safeguards," he said.
description: The Morrison government's scuttled facial recognition laws would have gone well beyond combating identify theft and national security threats.
